column1: An intrauterine device (IUD) is a small, plastic, T-shaped device used for birth control.
Progestin is a hormone used in many kinds of birth control pills.
Mirena can also treat heavy menstrual bleeding and reduce cramps.
- IUDs do not prevent sexually transmitted diseases (STDs).
- IUDs may increase the risk for ectopic pregnancy.
But women who use IUDs have a very low risk for getting pregnant.
- Some types of IUDs may increase the risk for benign ovarian cysts.
IUDs do not appear to increase the risk for pelvic infection.
